_description: Verses attached to a figure of a sphere in George Ripley’s Compound of Alchemy — six stanzas rhyme royal

CULFf223.Note: Stanzas 1-2 only; transcribed by Thomas Knyvet, 1545.

CamTCC1120.First Lines:
As holy script maketh mencionIn þe wombe of a virgin
                    immacvlat…
CamTCC1120.Last Lines:
…& to god both nyght & dayffor grace & for thy
                    auctor praye
CamTCC1120.Note: Written on, around, and below a figure of a sphere.
CamTCC1120.Attributed Title:
thys ffygure conteynyth all our secrettes both gret & small (f.
                        127v)

EDUDbII18.Editions:
Laing,  David. 
             Select Remains of the Ancient Popular and Romance Poetry of
                Scotland.
         Edinburgh: 1822; rev. 
                J.
                Small
            , Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1885; rev. 
                W. C.
                Hazlitt
            ,  “Early Popular Poetry of Scotland” , London: Reeves and
            Turner, 1895.

EDULaiii164.First Lines:
As holy scrypture makythe mensionin to þe wombe off a wyrgyn
                    immaculateChryste dessendyd for owr redemcionfro his hye trone to be
                    incarnate…
EDULaiii164.Last Lines:
…to his fyrste glory renyuyd with youtheassendythe to be
                    intronyȝate in þe sowthe
EDULaiii164.Note:
Copied 1510; four stanzas only, interspersed with English prose and some
                    Latin verses not translated (those for sun, moon, venus, mercury).
EDULaiii164.Editions:
Laing,  David.
